results.headline: When Sex Is Better Said Than Seen

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vulgaria

results.summary_short: In the comedy “Vulgaria” the Hong Kong filmmaker Pang Ho-Cheung would rather talk about sex than show it.

results.headline: Anti-Epic Flirts and Jokes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stars In Shorts

results.summary_short: “Stars in Shorts” is a collection of seven films, none longer than 25 minutes and starring notables like Judi Dench and Keira Knightley.

results.headline: A Fighting Puritan, Wielding an Arsenal Against Infidels

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Solomon Kane

results.summary_short: James Purefoy plays the title character in “Solomon Kane,” based on the Robert E. Howard novel.

results.headline: A Political Football in the Classroom

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Won't Back Down

results.summary_short: “Won’t Back Down,” an education drama that takes a good-versus-evil tack, stars Maggie Gyllenhaal and Viola Davis.

results.headline: Facing Pain in a Father’s Footsteps

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Six Million and One

results.summary_short: The filmmaker David Fisher and his three siblings retrace the steps of their Hungarian Jewish father, Joseph, a Holocaust survivor.

results.headline: A Collegiate A Cappella Group Puts on a Show

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pitch Perfect

results.summary_short: “Pitch Perfect” tells the story of the Bellas, a singing group fresh off a notable humiliation in a national competition.

results.headline: In What Universe Does This Guy Turn Into Bruce Willis?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Looper

results.summary_short: In Rian Johnson’s “Looper,” a young hit man (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) confronts his older self thanks to time travel.

results.headline: Basketball Hopes on the Baltic Sea

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Other Dream Team

results.summary_short: In the documentary “The Other Dream Team,” political history and sports mania merge.

results.headline: Boy Meets Girl, Boy Finds Out She’s 118

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hotel Transylvania

results.summary_short: In the vividly animated “Hotel Transylvania,” Dracula has a daughter who falls for a human backpacker who strays into their monsters-only inn.

results.headline: A Thai Tale Wrapped in a Smoky Noir

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Headshot

results.summary_short: Pen-ek Ratanaruang’s “Headshot” is a familiar story of good and evil with some contemporary touches.

results.headline: A Grifter Mom Tries to Reform

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bringing Up Bobby

results.summary_short: Famke Janssen’s “Bringing Up Bobby” focuses on a con artist desperate to support her 10-year-old son.

results.headline: A Place of Desperation, Where Both Patients and Patience Are Tested

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Waiting Room

results.summary_short: “The Waiting Room” looks at health care and suffering in an emergency room in Oakland, Calif.

results.headline: Folk Stories From Many Lands, Conjured With a Colorful Spin

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tales of the Night

results.summary_short: The animator Michel Ocelot gives a culturally diverse assortment of folk tales his own spin in “Tales of the Night.”

results.headline: Cloaked in the Horror of a Double Murder
results.display_title: House At the End of the Street

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of House At the End of the Street

results.summary_short: A mother and daughter move into a house in a neighborhood with a grim history in this unwieldy hybrid of “Psycho” and standard teenage horror films.

results.headline: On a Turbulent Journey to Modern Myanmar
results.display_title: They Call it Myanmar: Lifting the Curtain

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of They Call it Myanmar: Lifting the Curtain

results.summary_short: “They Call It Myanmar” explores the turbulent trajectory of this nation: its history, politics, culture and future.

results.headline: They Wouldn’t Take No for an Answer in the Battle Against AIDS

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How to Survive a Plague

results.summary_short: David France’s documentary “How to Survive a Plague” is a history of the fiery force of Act Up in the life-or-death fight for drugs to treat AIDS.

results.headline: Life Is a Feast, and She Wasn’t About to Starve
results.display_title: Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has to Travel

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has to Travel

results.summary_short: The documentary “Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has to Travel” takes a look at the doyenne of 20th-century fashion.

results.headline: Follow the Leader, to Extremes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 17 Girls

results.summary_short: When a high school alpha girl becomes pregnant, 16 other girls follow suit in the film “17 Girls,” which wavers between light comedy and drama.

results.headline: The Art of the Flutter

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Knuckleball!

results.summary_short: “Knuckleball!” follows two knuckleball pitchers, R. A. Dickey and Tim Wakefield, through the 2011 Major League Baseball season.

results.headline: Rooting for One Player in Baseball Politics: Dad

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trouble with the Curve

results.summary_short: “Trouble With the Curve” is the anti-“Moneyball.” The old-time scouts from that earlier film, mocked for their superstitions about “intangibles” and “instincts,” get their revenge this time around.
